text: at the holidays I'm all about making
people's lives easier so today I'm
sharing another great dessert it's a
pear and raspberry tart they couldn't be
easier to put together this is a piece
of puff pastry from a seventeen and a
half ounce box and I just stretched it a
little and then cut it into a nine and a
half inch square and I'm scoring don't
cut all the way through a border of 3/4
of an inch
get this into the freezer while you make
to prepare the filling is really easy in
a large bowl combine three-quarters of a
cup of raspberries works just as well
with frozen raspberries two tablespoons
of all-purpose flour 1/4 cup of sugar
just about two teaspoons of lemon juice
so it's from half of a lemon and 1/4
teaspoon of fine salt mash the berries
just a tiny bit and stir them together
with the flour and the sugar this is
gonna sit just for a few minutes and
begin to release some juices while you
prepare your pears you can set that
aside I have two small pears here they
should be firm but ripe that way they'll
hold their shape while they're baking
pears are a really great flavor to
combine with more acidic things like
raspberries or cranberries because
they're very sweet but they lack a bit
of acid you can use Bartlett or Anjou
and I'm using a combination of two
different kinds of pears cut them in
half and then you want to remove the
core I like to use a melon baller but
you can use a spoon as well just scoop
out the core with a melon baller should
come right out and also remove the stem
be sure to slice your pears right before
you need them so that they don't get
brown and they start to degrade quite
quickly I find you can use a melon
baller to remove the core of apples as
well I find it super useful for that
thinly slice your pears it really
doesn't matter which way you slice them
add your pears to the raspberry mixture
stir to combine and then the juice from
the pears is gonna moon the rest of that
flour and sugar when everything is fully
combined go get your puff pastry out of
the freezer
nice and cold cold puff pastry bakes the
best spoon you're filling within the
border that you cut what'll happen is as
your tart bakes the part where its cord
will puff up around the fruit creating a
really nice puffy border pears can be
pretty juicy that's why I added the
flower to this it's gonna act as a
thickener make sure that it's relatively
even it'll probably be a little bit
thicker than the center and a little
thinner towards the edges and that's
okay but you don't want a big huge pile
in the center and then nothing on the
edges okay that looks good brush the
edges with egg white the egg white will
give a nice shine to the edge of the
tart without getting it overly browned
now get this into a 400 degree oven and
bake for 15 minutes after 15 reduce the
temperature to 375 and bake until the
juices are bubbling and everything is
golden brown that'll take about 30 more
minutes if necessary if it's getting too
dark you can tent it with foil pretty
huh what I like to do is when it comes
out and there's a lot of warm juices
around I just lightly brushed the top of
all the fruit with some of the juices
that way when it cools down and you're
ready to eat it it's nice and shiny it
also gives the pears a little bit of a
pink hue because it's the juices of the
raspberries mixed with the pears you
don't really need to let this cool
completely before you eat it just let it
be not completely hot and then you can
enjoy
I think I'll enjoy them right now I
really think that you should try this as
an alternative dessert for Thanksgiving
because it's super duper easy and really
impressive and beautiful
hanging news from the raspberries sweet
anxiousness from the pears it's a match
made in heaven for Thanksgiving or any
day
